Jason Rogers wrote:

>     > > Can someone explain why someone (i.e. a customer) would 
>     > want to clutter
>     > > their storage or bandwith with test cases? 
>     > 
>     >  >
>     > 
>     > In general, if the customer is able to modify the 
>     > application source 
>     > code, then the test cases carry their weight.  Examples 
>     > include open 
>     > source applications or products where the source code is 
>     > the primary 
>     > deliverable (e.g. frameworks).
> 
> But Mike, don't you think this is a different beast altogether?  OpenSource
> should have the tests included because it fully expects the user to change
> the code.  If the user is responsible about maintaining the tests then it
> makes it easier for the progenitor(s) of the project accept changes to the
> base code.  At least in a somewhat perfect world... :D
> 
> -Jason
> 

No doubt, maintaining test cases is an excellent way to convince open 
source project curators that the changes work and don't break anything. 
  Moreover, the test cases are valuable stepping stones for users who 
don't plan to contribute their changes back to the user community.  In 
any event, the intent of shipping the test cases in these situations is 
to give users of source code confidence that the software works, 
document it's capabilities, and provide a testable foundation for 
modification.

I'll up the ante a bit and propose that products that provide a Java API 
ship selected JUnit test cases to demonstrate example uses of the API. 
It's common for such products to include example programs in various and 
sundry formats, and sometimes they even work!  I've often thought it 
would be handy if these examples followed a well known structure and 
automatically validated the results.  This of course requires that 
customers are willing to install JUnit if it's not distributed with the 
product.
